Class DataCheck

  • java.lang.Object
    • DataCheck

  •  class DataCheck
extends java.lang.Object
    Checks whether or not the user has entered a valid email address or phone number.
    Version:
    1.0 March 4, 2014
    Author:
    Joshua Yuan

    • Method Detail

      • checkEmail

        public static boolean checkEmail(java.lang.String email)
        Checks if the user has entered a valid email. The for loop is used to loop through each character in the email. Start: 0 Stop: email.length () The if structure checks for conditions that will make the email invalid.
        Parameters:
        email - String reference: Contains the email typed by the user.
        atSymbolLoc - int: Stores the location of the first @ symbol in the string.
        i - int: Used to iterate through all of the characters in the string.
        Returns:
        boolean: True if the following conditions are true:

        The email cannot contain consecutive periods, such as "..".

        A period cannot be the first or last character of the string.

        A period cannot be found immediately before or after the @ symbol.

        There must be exactly one @ symbol.

        There must be text before and after the @ symbol.

        Except for the @ symbol and the periods, all characters must be alphanumeric.

        No spaces are allowed.

      • checkPhone

        public static boolean checkPhone(java.lang.String phone)
        Checks if the user has entered a valid phone number. The first if structure checks if the length of the string is 10 or 12. The second if structure checks if a character which is expected to contain a digit does not contain a digit. The first and second ternary operators are used to alter the position of the characters that are checked, depending on the length of the string. The for loop iterates through the 10 characters in the string that are expected to contain a digit. Start: 0 Stop: 10
        Parameters:
        phone - String reference: Contains the phone number entered by the user.
        digit - array of ints: Contains the expected character position of digits for the xxx-xxx-xxxx and xxx xxx xxxx formats.
        i - int: Used to iterate through all of the characters in the string that are expected to contain digits.
        Returns:
        boolean: True for the following formats, where x represents a digit: xxx-xxx-xxxx, xxx xxx xxxx, or xxxxxxxxxx. Otherwise, it returns false.
